paragraphs.name: ee79
paragraphs.text: I’m tired of seeing new and frankly stupid redesigns of Facebook, Skype, and Twitter pop up on my newsfeed. Why not make something useful? Stop supporting these redesigns with likes, re-posts, and articles at Muzli, Medium, Designer News, etc. You’re aiding and abetting this brainless work. These designers may start to think that they are true professionals, and that they know more about how popular services should look than their creators.
Take a look at this woman’s approach: https://medium.freecodecamp.com/i-wanted-to-see-how-far-i-could-push-myself-creatively-so-i-redesigned-instagram-1ff99f28fa8b#.72jj409ck
paragraphs.name: a626

paragraphs.text: Thank a lot! Your work really impressed me and it’s so hard to find works with similar approach as you have.

paragraphs.text: Relax already. People are always experimenting, riffing, remixing…or just having fun. Collectively we’re creating a visual interface language, and these little snacks on the internet help jog new thoughts. Do you really want them to stop?
paragraphs.name: b005

68a738e9bf1c.title: It seems, however, that established web designers are always recommending this practice as a way to…

paragraphs.text: It seems, however, that established web designers are always recommending this practice as a way to gain experience. When I was trying to break into design I can’t tell you how many people suggested “if you want some experience try redesigning a popular service”. Obviously as a new designer there will be some rookie mistakes and the idea is you…
paragraphs.name: 81c9

fdbe2647f5ea.title: Yes! I was going to write an article similar to this myself (“Why concept art is bullshit”), but…

paragraphs.text: Yes! I was going to write an article similar to this myself (“Why concept art is bullshit”), but happy you did it. Muzli have been so criminal for reposting nonsense like this under the veil ‘Design Inspiration’. That Google redesign would be so intense on your eyes too! Going on Dribbble and typing in ‘[company] redesign’ yields some absolutely great results. All have lovely colours. All make absolutely no sense
paragraphs.name: 62fb

fb585ad3cafe.title: This is your blog and you can say what you want but I don´t agree.

paragraphs.text: This is your blog and you can say what you want but I don´t agree. What if I want to make a UI redesign of a product because I want clics or I need to compensate for a flimsy portfolio or just for fun? I understand your point but, please, let people do what they want. If a prefer to do an exercise of only my visual skills what the problem about that? So, maybe you hate our redesigns but I hate your post :)

89cf9a8ccff5.title: That’s the most stupid indignity I have ever read.

paragraphs.text: That’s the most stupid indignity I have ever read. Just change what appears in your newsfeed and let people do what they want. People who love their work + feel financial secure (FIRST!) will naturally look for charity work for free but let them grow in whatever way they want.

paragraphs.text: I recently started the redesign of official XBOX app on iPhone just because the current one looks like a cluttered Windows 10 mobile app with broken Information Architecture not because I thought the UI was boring or I needed something to design. So, I posted few screens on Dribbble hoping to get some feedback. Since, the UI was not fancy (read…

f23b745e9b65.title: Hate it or not, it does open doors for designers looking to make a dent in the market .

paragraphs.text: Hate it or not, it does open doors for designers looking to make a dent in the market . I did a linkedin redesign a long while back and the folks at LinkedIn reached out directly asking if I ever considered working for them. I passed on the offer as I wasn’t ready to move out west.

89e71c07d08c.title: With all due respect, I think you’re missing the point of unsolicited redesigns.

paragraphs.text: With all due respect, I think you’re missing the point of unsolicited redesigns. They are fun design explorations. No brand requirements, no product design restrictions, no insider information that would shackle ideas. No “this is the way we’ve always done it” debt, just pure exploration.
paragraphs.name: 81bc

virtuals.subtitle: Someone did an unsolicited redesign of my company and our team loved it. (https://dribbble.com/shots/2876030-Stackoverflow-redesign if you…

paragraphs.text: Good article! I noticed a lot of designers are designing for other designers instead of designing for users.

Isn’t this entire article hypocritical? People put effort into re-designs in order to drive a conversation about the pros & cons of the current UI. So yes, obviously a lot of them are worse than the existing, and outsiders are obviously not privy to internal business goals. But hosting a conversation about new ideas is completely valid, and actually…
paragraphs.name: 9f07

3e33f2c9d07c.title: Sometimes it’s not what you think looks pretty, but what your customers/users want and what makes…

paragraphs.text: Sometimes it’s not what you think looks pretty, but what your customers/users want and what makes sense in actual product planning. These are the realities to building software used by someone other then yourself.
paragraphs.name: 6e9b

dd9c40b2d404.title: These need to be taken for what they are — “fun craft practice.”

paragraphs.text: These need to be taken for what they are — “fun craft practice.” Practice of tools or reconstructing something to understand details of what was created, while escaping the hurdles of reality.
paragraphs.name: de8d

c220dfd6db87.title: Interesting article, I agree on the content, but not on the form.

paragraphs.text: Interesting article, I agree on the content, but not on the form. The mistake comes when you take these redesigns as business proposals, I think they should be viewed as visual exercises. As a designer there are few (and sometimes none) opportunities to experiment and bring innovative solutions to projects from the point of view of design.
paragraphs.name: 9c46
